study_title: Comprehensive functional characterization of SGCB coding variants predicts pathogenicity in limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type R4/2E
study_abstract: Genetic testing is essential for patients with a suspected hereditary myopathy. More than 50% of patients clinically diagnosed with a myopathy carry a variant of unknown significance in a myopathy gene, often leaving them without a genetic diagnosis. Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD) type R4/2E is caused by mutations in β-sarcoglycan (SGCB). Together, β-, α-, γ-, and δ-sarcoglycan form a 4-protein transmembrane complex (SGC) that localizes to the sarcolemma. Biallelic loss-of-function mutations in any subunit can lead to LGMD. To provide functional evidence for the pathogenicity of missense variants, we performed deep mutational scanning of SGCB and assessed SGC cell surface localization for all 6,340 possible amino acid changes. Variant functional scores were bimodally distributed and perfectly predicted pathogenicity of known variants. Variants with less severe functional scores more often appeared in patients with slower disease progression, implying a relationship between variant function and disease severity. Amino acid positions intolerant to variation mapped to points of predicted SGC interactions, validated in silico structural models, and enabled accurate prediction of pathogenic variants in other SGC genes. These results will be useful for clinical interpretation of SGCB variants and improving diagnosis of LGMD; we hope they enable wider use of potentially life-saving gene therapy.
study_short_summary: DMS of SGCB

study_title: DIMPLE: Deep insertion, deletion, and missense mutation libraries for exploring protein variation in evolution, disease, and biology
study_abstract: Insertions and deletions (indels) enable evolution and cause disease. Due to technical challenges, indels are left out of most mutational scans, limiting our understanding of them in disease, biology, and evolution. We developed a low cost and bias method, DIMPLE, for systematically generating deletions, insertions, and missense mutations in genes, which we test on a range of targets, including Kir2.1. We used DIMPLE to study how indels impact potassium channel structure, disease, and evolution. We find deletions are most disruptive overall, beta sheets are most sensitive to indels, and flexible loops are sensitive to deletions yet tolerate insertions.
study_short_summary: Surface expression deep mutational scan of mouse potassium channel Kir2.1 with indel-containing libraries generated with DIMPLE

study_abstract: We integrated three multiplexed assays to measure RNA abundance, protein abundance, and ribosome load for variants in the early coding region of the membrane-COMT (MB-COMT) protein isoform. Two regions that span clinically relevant variants (rs4633, rs4818, rs4680) in MB-COMT were targeted: codons 40-74 (region 1) and 136-158 (region 2). Our design enabled testing the importance of synonymous variation and a potential role of RNA secondary structure in controlling COMT gene expression.
study_short_summary: Integration of MAVEs to measure post-transcriptional gene expression for >3000 variants in COMT

study_abstract: This experiment measured the fitness of variants in the *NDUFAF6* gene in *Homo Sapiens*. Fitness of each variant was estimated based on its ability to rescue the growth defect of HEK293T NDUFAF6 KO cells in galactose media.
study_short_summary: Deep mutational scan of complex I assembly factor NDUFAF6
pub_title: Systematic analysis of NDUFAF6 in complex I assembly and mitochondrial disease.
pub_abstract: Isolated complex I (CI) deficiencies are a major cause of primary mitochondrial disease. A substantial proportion of CI deficiencies are believed to arise from defects in CI assembly factors (CIAFs) that are not part of the CI holoenzyme. The biochemistry of these CIAFs is poorly defined, making their role in CI assembly unclear, and confounding interpretation of potential disease-causing genetic variants. To address these challenges, we devised a deep mutational scanning approach to systematically assess the function of thousands of NDUFAF6 genetic variants. Guided by these data, biochemical analyses and cross-linking mass spectrometry, we discovered that the CIAF NDUFAF6 facilitates incorporation of NDUFS8 into CI and reveal that NDUFS8 overexpression rectifies NDUFAF6 deficiency. Our data further provide experimental support of pathogenicity for seven novel NDUFAF6 variants associated with human pathology and introduce functional evidence for over 5,000 additional variants. Overall, our work defines the molecular function of NDUFAF6 and provides a clinical resource for aiding diagnosis of NDUFAF6-related diseases.

study_title: Functional classification of 331 clinical KCNQ2 variants
study_abstract: Epilepsy is the second leading neurological disorder worldwide. Channel dysfunction caused by KCNQ2 variants leads to benign familial neonatal seizures and epileptic encephalopathy. As one of the most common epilepsy-associated genes, KCNQ2 variants explosively emerge in recent years. However, the paucity of functional interpretation on variants hinders the diagnosis and treatment of KCNQ2-related diseases. Here, we collected 331 clinically significant KCNQ2 variants: 145 from 232 epilepsy patients and other 186 missense variants from ClinVar database. To get enough negative controls, we also selected all 14 B/LB missense variants from ClinVar database and 43 synonymous variants with the minor allele frequency (MAF) greater than the incidence of KCNQ2-related disorders (0.0059%) from the gnomAD database as benign controls. All variants were performed electrophysiologic analysis and functional classification when expressed as homomeric mutant channel and as heteromeric mutant/wild type channel.
study_short_summary: Electrophysiologic analysis of clinical KCNQ2 variants (205 missense variants, 30 non-missense and 43 synonymous variants)

study_title: Deep mutational scanning quantifies DNA binding and predicts clinical outcomes of PAX6 variants
study_abstract: Nonsense and missense mutations in the transcription factor PAX6 cause a wide range of eye development defects, including aniridia, microphthalmia and coloboma. To understand how changes of PAX6:DNA binding cause these phenotypes, we combined saturation mutagenesis of the paired domain of PAX6 with a yeast one-hybrid (Y1H) assay in which expression of a PAX6-GAL4 fusion gene drives antibiotic resistance. We quantified binding of more than 2,700 single amino-acid variants to two DNA sequence elements. Mutations in DNA-facing residues of the N-terminal subdomain and linker region were most detrimental, as were mutations to prolines and to negatively charged residues. Many variants caused sequence-specific molecular gain-of-function effects, including variants in position Ile71 that increased binding to the LE9 enhancer but decreased binding to a SELEX-derived binding site. In the absence of antibiotic selection, variants that retained DNA binding slowed yeast growth, likely because such variants perturbed the yeast transcriptome. Benchmarking against known patient variants and applying ACMG/AMP guidelines to variant classification, we obtained supporting to moderate evidence to suggest that 1,306 variants are likely benign, and 977, likely pathogenic. Our analysis shows that most pathogenic mutations in the paired domain of PAX6 can be explained simply by the effects of these mutations on PAX6:DNA association, and establishes Y1H as a generalisable assay for the interpretation of variant effects in transcription factors.
study_short_summary: A deep mutational scanning study of the paired domain of human transcription factor PAX6, with a DNA-binding readout measured using a yeast antibiotic resistance assay (yeast one-hybrid assay).
keywords: PAX6, transcription factor, yeast one-hybrid, Y1H DNA binding

study_title: Effects on antibody escape of mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.1
study_abstract: We present a deep mutational scanning (DMS) assay to measure the effect of single amino acid mutations across the entire Receptor Binding Domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein on antibody escape for Omicron BA.1. The generated escape map revealed that Omicron BA.1 has a higher number of escape mutations compared to its predecessor Delta, suggesting that it may be less susceptible to neutralization by currently available antibody therapies. The data also demonstrated that a large proportion of Omicron BA.1 escape mutations make the RBD more similar to the bat-CoV RBD, which may suggest an increased adaptation to transmission dynamics or host cells and which creates a novel evolutionary trajectory. Furthermore, several Omicron BA.1 mutations lie in close proximity to RBD-ACE2 interaction residues and may directly block antibody binding while maintaining ACE2 binding. See the paper for more information.
study_short_summary: This experiment measures the effects on antibody escape of variants in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.1
pub_title: Deep mutational scans for ACE2 binding, RBD expression, and antibody escape in the SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.1 and BA.2 receptor-binding domains.
pub_abstract: SARS-CoV-2 continues to acquire mutations in the spike receptor-binding domain (RBD) that impact ACE2 receptor binding, folding stability, and antibody recognition. Deep mutational scanning prospectively characterizes the impacts of mutations on these biochemical properties, enabling rapid assessment of new mutations seen during viral surveillance. However, the effects of mutations can change as the virus evolves, requiring updated deep mutational scans. We determined the impacts of all single amino acid mutations in the Omicron BA.1 and BA.2 RBDs on ACE2-binding affinity, RBD folding, and escape from binding by the LY-CoV1404 (bebtelovimab) monoclonal antibody. The effects of some mutations in Omicron RBDs differ from those measured in the ancestral Wuhan-Hu-1 background. These epistatic shifts largely resemble those previously seen in the Alpha variant due to the convergent epistatically modifying N501Y substitution. However, Omicron variants show additional lineage-specific shifts, including examples of the epistatic phenomenon of entrenchment that causes the Q498R and N501Y substitutions present in Omicron to be more favorable in that background than in earlier viral strains. In contrast, the Omicron substitution Q493R exhibits no sign of entrenchment, with the derived state, R493, being as unfavorable for ACE2 binding in Omicron RBDs as in Wuhan-Hu-1. Likely for this reason, the R493Q reversion has occurred in Omicron sub-variants including BA.4/BA.5 and BA.2.75, where the affinity buffer from R493Q reversion may potentiate concurrent antigenic change. Consistent with prior studies, we find that Omicron RBDs have reduced expression, and identify candidate stabilizing mutations that ameliorate this deficit. Last, our maps highlight a broadening of the sites of escape from LY-CoV1404 antibody binding in BA.1 and BA.2 compared to the ancestral Wuhan-Hu-1 background. These BA.1 and BA.2 deep mutational scanning datasets identify shifts in the RBD mutational landscape and inform ongoing efforts in viral surveillance.

Furthermore, several Omicron BA.2 mutations lie in close proximity to RBD-ACE2 interaction residues and may directly block antibody binding while maintaining ACE2 binding. study_title: Effects on ACE2-binding affinity of mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.1
study_abstract: The experiment aimed to determine the impact of mutations in the Omicron BA.1 RBD of the SARS-CoV-2 virus on their binding affinity to the human ACE2 receptor. Deep mutational scanning was used to analyze every possible single amino acid substitution in the Omicron BA.1 RBD, and their subsequent binding affinity with human ACE2 receptor was identified. Several mutations reduced the binding affinity of the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.1 for its receptor, as expected. However, several new mutations were found which increased binding affinity, indicating the potential evolution of the virus. These mutations were clustered at several sites and caused subtle shifts to regions critical for receptor-ACE2 interactions. The experiment is described in more detail in the paper.
study_short_summary: This experiment measures the effects on ACE2-binding affinity of variants in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.1
pub_title: Deep mutational scans for ACE2 binding, RBD expression, and antibody escape in the SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.1 and BA.2 receptor-binding domains.

study_title: Effects on RBD expression of mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.1
study_abstract: The experiment aimed to determine the impact of mutations in the Omicron BA.1 RBD of the SARS-CoV-2 virus on the expression of the RBD on the surface of yeast cells. Deep mutational scanning was used to analyze every possible single amino acid substitution in the Omicron BA.1 RBD, and their subsequent expression was identified. Results showed that the Omicron BA.1 RBD mutants have lower surface expression levels relative to Wuhan-Hu-1, indicating a potential reduction in viral infectivity. The experiment is described in more detail in the paper.
study_short_summary: This experiment measures the effects on RBD expression of variants in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.1
pub_title: Deep mutational scans for ACE2 binding, RBD expression, and antibody escape in the SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.1 and BA.2 receptor-binding domains.
pub_abstract: SARS-CoV-2 continues to acquire mutations in the spike receptor-binding domain (RBD) that impact ACE2 receptor binding, folding stability, and antibody recognition. Deep mutational scanning prospectively characterizes the impacts of mutations on these biochemical properties, enabling rapid assessment of new mutations seen during viral surveillance. However, the effects of mutations can change as the virus evolves, requiring updated deep mutational scans. We determined the impacts of all single amino acid mutations in the Omicron BA.1 and BA.2 RBDs on ACE2-binding affinity, RBD folding, and escape from binding by the LY-CoV1404 (bebtelovimab) monoclonal antibody. The effects of some mutations in Omicron RBDs differ from those measured in the ancestral Wuhan-Hu-1 background. These epistatic shifts largely resemble those previously seen in the Alpha variant due to the convergent epistatically modifying N501Y substitution. However, Omicron variants show additional lineage-specific shifts, including examples of the epistatic phenomenon of entrenchment that causes the Q498R and N501Y substitutions present in Omicron to be more favorable in that background than in earlier viral strains. In contrast, the Omicron substitution Q493R exhibits no sign of entrenchment, with the derived state, R493, being as unfavorable for ACE2 binding in Omicron RBDs as in Wuhan-Hu-1. Likely for this reason, the R493Q reversion has occurred in Omicron sub-variants including BA.4/BA.5 and BA.2.75, where the affinity buffer from R493Q reversion may potentiate concurrent antigenic change. Consistent with prior studies, we find that Omicron RBDs have reduced expression, and identify candidate stabilizing mutations that ameliorate this deficit. Last, our maps highlight a broadening of the sites of escape from LY-CoV1404 antibody binding in BA.1 and BA.2 compared to the ancestral Wuhan-Hu-1 background. These BA.1 and BA.2 deep mutational scanning datasets identify shifts in the RBD mutational landscape and inform ongoing efforts in viral surveillance.

study_title: Effects on ACE2-binding affinity of mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.2
study_abstract: The experiment aimed to determine the impact of mutations in the Omicron BA.2 RBD of the SARS-CoV-2 virus on their binding affinity to the human ACE2 receptor. Deep mutational scanning was used to analyze every possible single amino acid substitution in the Omicron BA.2 RBD, and their subsequent binding affinity with human ACE2 receptor was identified. The Omicron BA.2 RBD was found to have greater tolerance to mutations than the Omicron BA.1 RBD, with mutational effects tending to have smaller effects on ACE2 binding affinity. New mutations were also found to increase the binding affinity of the Omicron BA.2 RBD for human ACE2 receptor. These mutations were clustered at several common sites, many of which overlap with those found in the Omicron BA.1 analysis. The experiment is described in more detail in the paper.
study_short_summary: This experiment measures the effects on ACE2-binding affinity of variants in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.2

study_title: Effects on RBD expression of mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.2
study_abstract: The experiment aimed to determine the impact of mutations in the Omicron BA.2 RBD of the SARS-CoV-2 virus on the expression of the RBD on the surface of yeast cells. Deep mutational scanning was used to analyze every possible single amino acid substitution in the Omicron BA.2 RBD, and their subsequent expression was identified. Results showed that the Omicron BA.2 RBD mutants have lower surface expression levels relative to Wuhan-Hu-1, indicating a potential reduction in infectivity. The experiment is described in more detail in the paper.
study_short_summary: This experiment measures the effects on RBD expression of variants in the SARS-CoV-2 RBD Omicron BA.2

study_title: Mutational Profiling of SARS-CoV-2 PLpro in human cells reveals requirements for function, structure, and drug escape
study_abstract:
Papain-like protease (PLpro) is critical to SARS-CoV-2 replication and immune evasion and is an attractive target for therapeutic development to treat COVID19. We designed two assays to interrogate the sequence-function requirements of PLpro. The first assay measures PLpro activity directly using a cleavable biosensor comprising mClover3 and mRuby3 separated by a PLpro cleavable linker. The second assay measures PLpro abundance by the installation of mClover3 as a C-terminal fusion. Both assays allow PLpro activity and abundance to be monitored in mammalian cells by flow cytometry.

Deep mutational scanning libraries were designed for each assay. The first library used in activity-based screens contains unmodified PLpro (a subdomain of NSP3) under doxycycline control. The second library contains constitutively expressed PLpro-mClover3 and is used in the abundance screen. Both libraries are barcoded 3' to the PLpro stop codon and long-read sequencing was used to map barcodes and variants prior to commencing screens. We screened for PLpro activity, escape from dox control, and escape from two inhibitor compounds 3k and 5c, in addition to PLpro abundance. Because 3k and 5c are similar in structure we also deposit a combined dataset showing elucidating residues that are critical to maintaining PLpro susceptibility to both compounds.
study_short_summary: DMS dataset for PLpro Activity against FRET biosensor.

study_title: Cell Surface and Functional Scores for KCNE1
study_abstract: In this study, we generated cell surface expression scores for HA-tagged KCNE1 in HEK293T cells in the presence and absence of KCNQ1 for 2,559/2,709 variants. We also generated fitness scores for 2,534/2,709 KCNE1 variants in HEK293T cells in the presence of a gain-of-function KCNQ1 variant (S140G).
study_short_summary: This study contains three multiplexed assays of KCNE1 variants
pub_title: High-throughput functional mapping of variants in an arrhythmia gene,
pub_abstract: KCNE1 encodes a 129-residue cardiac potassium channel (IKs) subunit. KCNE1 variants are associated with long QT syndrome and atrial fibrillation. However, most variants have insufficient evidence of clinical consequences and thus limited clinical utility. Here, we demonstrate the power of variant effect mapping, which couples saturation mutagenesis with high-throughput sequencing, to ascertain the function of thousands of protein coding KCNE1 variants. We comprehensively assayed KCNE1 variant cell surface expression (2,554/2,709 possible single amino acid variants) and function (2,539 variants). We identified 470 loss-of-surface expression and 588 loss-of-function variants. Out of the 588 loss-of-function variants, only 155 had low cell surface expression. The latter half of the protein is dispensable for protein trafficking but essential for channel function. 22 of the 30 KCNE1 residues (73%) highly intolerant of variation were in predicted close contact with binding partners KCNQ1 or calmodulin. Our data were highly concordant with gold standard electrophysiological data (ρ = -0.65), population and patient cohorts (32/38 concordant variants), and computational metrics (ρ = -0.55). Our data provide moderate-strength evidence for the ACMG/AMP functional criteria for benign and pathogenic variants. Comprehensive variant effect maps of KCNE1 can both provide insight into IKs channel biology and help reclassify variants of uncertain significance.

study_abstract: This study measured the stability of the SH3 domain in ABL1 using a DHFR protein-fragment complementation assay that couples the cellular abundance of the target protein expressed in yeast to yeast growth. The identifier used in the original study is P00519_PF00018_64.
study_short_summary: Stability measurements of the ABL1 SH3 domain from domainome 1.0.
pub_title: Site saturation mutagenesis of 500 human protein domains reveals the contribution of protein destabilization to genetic disease
pub_abstract: Missense variants that change the amino acid sequences of proteins cause one third of human genetic diseases1. Tens of millions of missense variants exist in the current human population, with the vast majority having unknown functional consequences. Here we present the first large-scale experimental analysis of human missense variants across many different proteins. Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

pub_title: Site saturation mutagenesis of 500 human protein domains reveals the contribution of protein destabilization to genetic disease
pub_abstract: Missense variants that change the amino acid sequences of proteins cause one third of human genetic diseases1. Tens of millions of missense variants exist in the current human population, with the vast majority having unknown functional consequences. Here we present the first large-scale experimental analysis of human missense variants across many different proteins. Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

study_abstract: This study measured the stability of the Homeobox domain in ALX4 using a DHFR protein-fragment complementation assay that couples the cellular abundance of the target protein expressed in yeast to yeast growth. The identifier used in the original study is Q9H161_PF00046_216.

study_short_summary: Stability measurements of the BPTF Zinc finger, PHD-finger domain from domainome 1.0.
pub_title: Site saturation mutagenesis of 500 human protein domains reveals the contribution of protein destabilization to genetic disease
pub_abstract: Missense variants that change the amino acid sequences of proteins cause one third of human genetic diseases1. Tens of millions of missense variants exist in the current human population, with the vast majority having unknown functional consequences. Here we present the first large-scale experimental analysis of human missense variants across many different proteins. Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

pub_abstract: Missense variants that change the amino acid sequences of proteins cause one third of human genetic diseases1. Tens of millions of missense variants exist in the current human population, with the vast majority having unknown functional consequences. Here we present the first large-scale experimental analysis of human missense variants across many different proteins. Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

Tens of millions of missense variants exist in the current human population, with the vast majority having unknown functional consequences. Here we present the first large-scale experimental analysis of human missense variants across many different proteins. Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

study_abstract: This study measured the stability of the SAM domain in EPS8 using a DHFR protein-fragment complementation assay that couples the cellular abundance of the target protein expressed in yeast to yeast growth. The identifier used in the original study is Q12929_PF18016_720.
study_short_summary: Stability measurements of the EPS8 SAM domain from domainome 1.0.

pub_abstract: Missense variants that change the amino acid sequences of proteins cause one third of human genetic diseases1. Tens of millions of missense variants exist in the current human population, with the vast majority having unknown functional consequences. Here we present the first large-scale experimental analysis of human missense variants across many different proteins. Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

pub_title: Site saturation mutagenesis of 500 human protein domains reveals the contribution of protein destabilization to genetic disease
pub_abstract: Missense variants that change the amino acid sequences of proteins cause one third of human genetic diseases1. Tens of millions of missense variants exist in the current human population, with the vast majority having unknown functional consequences. Here we present the first large-scale experimental analysis of human missense variants across many different proteins. Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.

Here we present the first large-scale experimental analysis of human missense variants across many different proteins. Using DNA synthesis and cellular selection experiments we quantify the impact of >500,000 variants on the abundance of >500 human protein domains. This dataset - Human Domainome 1.0 - reveals that >60% of pathogenic missense variants reduce protein stability. The contribution of stability to protein fitness varies across proteins and diseases, and is particularly important in recessive disorders. We show how stability measurements can be combined with protein language models to annotate functional sites and that measurements made on a small number of proteins can be used to accurately predict stability changes across entire protein families using energy models. Domainome 1.0 demonstrates the feasibility of assaying human protein variants at scale and provides a large consistent reference dataset for clinical variant interpretation and the training and benchmarking of computational methods.
